with the upper bound found in [35]. For the lower bound, the example ğ‘“(ğ‘§) = ğ‘§ğ‘›âˆ’1 shows that ğ¶6.20(ğ‘›) â‰¥1,
while the example ğ‘“(ğ‘§) = ğ‘§ğ‘›âˆ’ğ‘§shows the slightly weaker ğ¶6.20(ğ‘›) â‰¥ğ‘›âˆ’1
ğ‘›âˆ’1 . The first example can be generalized
to ğ‘“(ğ‘§) = ğ‘(ğ‘§ğ‘›âˆ’ğ‘’ğ‘–ğœƒ) for ğ‘â‰ 0 and real ğœƒ; it is conjectured in [229] that these are the only extremal examples.
Sendovâ€™s conjecture was first proved by Meirâ€“Sharma [211] for ğ‘›< 6, Brown [46] (ğ‘›< 7), Borcea [38] and
Brown [47] (ğ‘›< 8), Brown-Xiang [48] (ğ‘›< 9) and Tao [279] for sufficiently large ğ‘›. However, it remains open
for medium-sized ğ‘›.
We tried to rediscover the ğ‘“(ğ‘§) = ğ‘§ğ‘›âˆ’1 example that gives the lower bound ğ¶6.20(ğ‘›) â‰¥1 and aimed to investigate
its uniqueness. To do so, we instructed AlphaEvolve to choose over the set of all sets of ğ‘›roots {ğœğ‘—}ğ‘›
ğ‘—=1. The
score computation went as follows. First, if any of the roots were outside of the unit disk, we projected them onto
the unit circle. Next, using the numpy.poly, numpy.polyder, and np.roots functions, we computed the roots
ğœ‰ğ‘—of ğ‘â€²(ğ‘§) and returned the maximum over ğœğ‘–of the distance between ğœğ‘–and the {ğœ‰ğ‘—}ğ‘›âˆ’1
ğ‘—=1. AlphaEvolve found
the expected maximizers ğ‘(ğ‘§) = (ğ‘§ğ‘›âˆ’ğ‘’ğ‘–ğœƒ) and near-maximizers such as ğ‘(ğ‘§) = ğ‘§ğ‘›âˆ’ğ‘§, but did not discover any
additional maximizers.
Problem 6.21 (Schmeisserâ€™s conjecture). . For each ğ‘›â‰¥2, let ğ¶6.21(ğ‘›) be the smallest constant such that for
any complex polynomial ğ‘“of degree ğ‘›â‰¥2 with zeros ğ‘§1, â€¦ , ğ‘§ğ‘›in the unit disk and critical points ğ‘¤1, â€¦ , ğ‘¤ğ‘›âˆ’1,
and for any nonnegative weights ğ‘™1, â€¦ , ğ‘™ğ‘›â‰¥0 satisfying âˆ‘ğ‘›
ğ‘˜=1 ğ‘™ğ‘˜= 1, we have
min
1â‰¤ğ‘—â‰¤ğ‘›âˆ’1
|||||
ğ‘›
âˆ‘
ğ‘˜=1
ğ‘™ğ‘˜ğ‘§ğ‘˜âˆ’ğ‘¤ğ‘—
|||||
â‰¤ğ¶6.21(ğ‘›).
It was conjectured in [251, 252] that ğ¶6.21(ğ‘›) = 1.
Clearly ğ¶6.21(ğ‘›) â‰¥ğ¶6.20(ğ‘›). This is stronger than Sendovâ€™s conjecture and we hoped to disprove it. As in
the previous subsection, we instructed AlphaEvolve to maximize over sets of roots. Given a set of roots, we
deterministically picked many points on their convex hull (midpoints of line segments and points that divide line
segments in the ratio 2:1), and computed their distances from the critical points. AlphaEvolve did not manage
to find a counterexample to this conjecture. All the best constructions discovered by AlphaEvolve had all roots
and critical points near the boundary of the circle. By forcing some of the roots to be far from the boundary of
the disk one can get insights about what the â€œnext bestâ€ constructions look like, see Figure 14.


--- Page 32 ---
32

such that for any complex polynomial ğ‘“of degree ğ‘›with zeroes ğ‘§1, â€¦ , ğ‘§ğ‘›satisfying
1
ğ‘›
ğ‘›
âˆ‘
ğ‘–=1
|ğ‘§ğ‘–|ğ‘â‰¤1,
(6.7)
and every zero ğ‘“(ğœ) = 0 of ğ‘“, there exists a critical point ğ‘“â€²(ğœ‰) = 0 of ğ‘“with |ğœ‰âˆ’ğœ| â‰¤ğ¶6.22(ğ‘, ğ‘›). What is
ğ¶6.22(ğ‘, ğ‘›)?
From HÃ¶lderâ€™s inequality, ğ¶6.22(ğ‘, ğ‘›) is non-increasing in ğ‘and tends to ğ¶Sendov(ğ‘›) in the limit ğ‘â†’âˆ. It was
conjectured by Borcea3 [181, Conjecture 1] that ğ¶6.22(ğ‘, ğ‘›) = 1 for all 1 â‰¤ğ‘< âˆand ğ‘›â‰¥2. This version is
stronger than Sendovâ€™s conjecture and therefore potentially easier to disprove. The cases ğ‘= 1, ğ‘= 2 are of
particular interest; the (ğ‘, ğ‘›) = (1, 3), (2, 4) cases were verified in [181].
We focused our efforts on the ğ‘= 1 case. Using a similar implementation to the earlier problems in this section,
AlphaEvolve proposed various ğ‘§ğ‘›âˆ’ğ‘›ğ‘§and ğ‘§ğ‘›âˆ’ğ‘›ğ‘§ğ‘›âˆ’1 type constructions. We tried several ways to push
AlphaEvolve away from polynomials of this form by giving it a penalty if its construction was similar to these
known examples, but ultimately we did not find a counterexample to this conjecture.

We tested the ability of AlphaEvolve to recover the lower bound on ğ¶6.23(ğ‘›) with a similar setup as in the
previous problems. Given a set of roots, we evaluated the corresponding polynomial on points ğ‘§given by a 2D

also some other constructions with similar score (see Figure 15), but it did not manage to find a counterexample.
Now we turn to a variant where the parameters one wishes to optimize range in a two-dimensional space.
Problem 6.24 (de Bruinâ€“Sharma). For ğ‘›â‰¥4, let Î©6.24(ğ‘›) be the set of pairs (ğ›¼, ğ›½) âˆˆâ„2
+ such that, whenever

.
3In the notation of [181], the condition (6.7) implies that ğœğ‘(ğ¹) â‰¤1, where ğ¹(ğ‘§) âˆ¶= (ğ‘§âˆ’ğ‘§1) â€¦ (ğ‘§âˆ’ğ‘§ğ‘›), and the claim that a critical
point lies within distance 1 of any zero is the assertion that â„(ğ¹, ğ¹â€²) â‰¤1. Thus, the statement of Borceaâ€™s conjecture given here is equivalent
to that in [181, Conjecture 1] after normalizing the set of zeroes by a dilation and translation.

They then conjectured that this point was in Î©6.24(ğ‘›), a claim that was subsequently verified in [58].
From Cauchyâ€“Schwarz one has the inequalities
(|ğ‘§1|2 + â‹¯+ |ğ‘§ğ‘›|2)2 â‰¤ğ‘›(|ğ‘§1|4 + â‹¯+ |ğ‘§ğ‘›|4)
(6.9)
and from simple expansion of the square we have
(|ğ‘§1|4 + â‹¯+ |ğ‘§ğ‘›|4) â‰¤(|ğ‘§1|2 + â‹¯+ |ğ‘§ğ‘›|2)2
(6.10)

By convexity and monotonicity, we further conclude that Î©6.24(ğ‘›) contains the region above and to the right of

When initially running our experiments, we had the belief that this was in fact the complete description of the
feasible set Î©6.24(ğ‘›). We tasked AlphaEvolve to confirm this by producing polynomials that excluded various
half-planes of pairs (ğ›¼, ğ›½) as infeasible, with the score function equal to minus the area of the surviving region
(restricted to the unit square). To our surprise, AlphaEvolve indicated that the feasible region was slightly larger:
the ğ‘¥-intercept ( ğ‘›âˆ’2
ğ‘›, 0) could be lowered to ( ğ‘›3âˆ’2ğ‘›2+3ğ‘›âˆ’14
ğ‘›(ğ‘›2+3)
, 0) when ğ‘›was odd, but was numerically confirmed
when ğ‘›was even; and the ğ‘¦-intercept (0, ğ‘›2âˆ’4ğ‘›+2
ğ‘›2
) could be improved to (0, (ğ‘›âˆ’2)4+ğ‘›âˆ’2
ğ‘›2(ğ‘›âˆ’1)2 ) for both odd and even
ğ‘›. By an inspection of the polynomials used by AlphaEvolve to obtain these regions, we realized that these
improvements were related to the requirement that the zeroes ğ‘§1, â€¦ , ğ‘§ğ‘›sum to zero. Indeed, equality in (6.9)
only holds when all the ğ‘§ğ‘–are of equal magnitude; but if they are also required to be real (which as previously
discussed was a key case), then they could not also sum to zero when ğ‘›was odd except in the degenerate case
where all the ğ‘§ğ‘–vanished. Similarly, equality in (6.10) only holds when just one of the ğ‘§1, â€¦ , ğ‘§ğ‘›is non-zero,
but this is obviously incompatible with the requirement of summing to zero except in the degenerate case. The
ğ‘¥-intercept numerically provided by AlphaEvolve instead came from a real-rooted polynomial with two zeroes
whose multiplicity was as close to ğ‘›âˆ•2 as possible, while still summing to zero; and the ğ‘¦-intercept numerically
provided by AlphaEvolve similarly came from considering a polynomial of the form (ğ‘§âˆ’ğ‘)ğ‘›âˆ’1(ğ‘§+ (ğ‘›âˆ’1)ğ‘)
for some (any) non-zero ğ‘. Thus this experiment provided an example in which AlphaEvolve was able to notice
an oversight in the analysis by the human authors.
Based on this analysis and the numerical evidence from AlphaEvolve, we now propose the following conjectured
inequalities
|ğœ‰1|4 + â‹¯+ |ğœ‰ğ‘›âˆ’1|4 â‰¤ğ‘›3 âˆ’2ğ‘›2 + 3ğ‘›âˆ’14

(|ğ‘§1|4 + â‹¯+ |ğ‘§ğ‘›|4)

for odd ğ‘›> 4, and
|ğœ‰1|4 + â‹¯+ |ğœ‰ğ‘›âˆ’1|4 â‰¤(ğ‘›âˆ’2)4 + ğ‘›âˆ’2
ğ‘›2(ğ‘›âˆ’1)2
(|ğ‘§1|2 + â‹¯+ |ğ‘§ğ‘›|2)2
for all ğ‘›â‰¥4. After the initial release of this paper, these two inequalities were established by Tang [278], using
a new interpolation-based approach to the de Bruinâ€“Sharma inequalities.

11. Sidorenkoâ€™s conjecture.
Problem 6.26 (Sidorenkoâ€™s conjecture). A graphon is a symmetric measurable function ğ‘Šâˆ¶[0, 1]2 â†’[0, 1].
Given a graphon ğ‘Šand a finite graph ğ»= (ğ‘‰(ğ»), ğ¸(ğ»)), the homomorphism density ğ‘¡(ğ», ğ‘Š) is defined as
ğ‘¡(ğ», ğ‘Š) = âˆ«[0,1]ğ‘‰(ğ»)
âˆ
{ğ‘£,ğ‘¤}âˆˆğ¸(ğ»)
ğ‘Š(ğ‘¥ğ‘£, ğ‘¥ğ‘¤)
âˆ
ğ‘£âˆˆğ‘‰(ğ»)
ğ‘‘ğ‘¥ğ‘£.
For a finite bipartite graph ğ», let ğ¶6.26(ğ») denote the least constant for which
ğ‘¡(ğ», ğ‘Š) â‰¥ğ‘¡(ğ¾2, ğ‘Š)ğ¶6.26(ğ»)
holds for all graphons ğ‘Š, where ğ¾2 is the complete graph on two vertices. What is ğ¶6.26(ğ»)?
By setting the graphon ğ‘Što be constant, we see that ğ¶6.26(ğ») â‰¥|ğ¸(ğ»)|. Graphs for which ğ¶6.26(ğ») = |ğ¸(ğ»)|
are said to have the Sidorenko property, and the Sidorenko conjecture [259] asserts that all bipartite graphs
have this property. Sidorenko [259] proved this conjecture for complete bipartite graphs, even cycles and trees,
and for bipartite graphs with at most four vertices on one side. Hatami [163] showed that hypercubes satisfy
Sidorenkoâ€™s conjecture. Conlonâ€“Foxâ€“Sudakov [72] proved it for bipartite graphs with a vertex which is complete
to the other side, generalized later to reflection trees by Liâ€“Szegedy [197]. See also results by Kimâ€“Leeâ€“Lee,
Conlonâ€“Kimâ€“Leeâ€“Lee, Szegedy and Conlonâ€“Lee for further classes for which the conjecture has been proved
[74, 73, 182, 273, 75].
The smallest bipartite graph for which the Sidorenko property is not known to hold is the graph obtained by
removing a 10-cycle from ğ¾5,5. Setting this graph as ğ», we used AlphaEvolve to search for a graphon ğ‘Š
which violates Sidorenkoâ€™s inequality. As constant graphons trivially give equality, we added an extra penalty
if the proposed ğ‘Šwas close to constant. Despite various attempts along such directions, we did not manage to
find a counterexample to this conjecture.

to problems in analytic number theory, we explored the following classic problem:

6.27?
The celebrated prime number theorem answers Problem 6.27 by showing that
ğ¶âˆ’

6.27 = 1.

âˆ‘

ğ¶âˆ’

0.992619â‹¯â‰¤ğ¶âˆ’
6.27 â‰¤ğ¶+
6.27 â‰¤1.006774 â€¦
of Sylvester [272] can be obtained by this method.
It turns out that good choices of ğœˆtend to be truncated versions of the MÃ¶bius function ğœ‡(ğ‘›), defined to equal
(âˆ’1)ğ‘—when ğ‘›is the product of ğ‘—distinct primes, and zero otherwise. Thus,
ğœ‡= ğ‘’1 âˆ’ğ‘’2 âˆ’ğ‘’3 âˆ’ğ‘’5 + ğ‘’6 âˆ’ğ‘’7 â€¦
We tested AlphaEvolve on constructing lower bounds for this problem. To make this task more difficult for
AlphaEvolve, we only asked it to produce a partial function which maximizes a hidden evaluation function that
has something to do with number theory. We did not tell AlphaEvolve explicitly what problem it was working
on. In the prompt, we also asked AlphaEvolve to look at the previous best function it has constructed and to
try to guess the general form of the solution. With this setup, AlphaEvolve recognized the importance of the
MÃ¶bius function, and found various natural constructions that work with factors of a composite number, and
others that work with truncations of a MÃ¶bius function. In the end, using this blind setup, its final score of 0.938
fell short of the best known lower bound mentioned above.

Extensive numerical calculations (30 CPU-years, with ğ‘›as large as 100) by Odlyzko [225] suggested that

To this end we used our standard search mode where we explored AlphaEvolveâ€™s performance towards find-
ing lower bounds for ğ¶âˆ’
6.28 and upper bounds for ğ¶+
6.28. The evaluation is based on computing the minimum
(resp. maximum) of the quantity |ğ‘(ğ‘§)|âˆ•
âˆš
ğ‘›+ 1 over the unit circle - to this end, we sample ğ‘(ğ‘§) on a dense
mesh {ğ‘’2ğœ‹ğ‘–ğ‘˜âˆ•ğ¾}ğ¾
ğ‘˜=1 for ğ‘˜= 1, â€¦ , ğ¾,. The accuracy of the evaluator depends on ğ‘›, ğ¾- in our experiments for
ğ‘›â‰¤100 (and keeping in mind that the coefficients of the polynomials are Â±1) we find working with ğ¾= 6, 7
as a reasonable balance between accuracy and evaluation speed during AlphaEvolveâ€™s program evolutions;
post completion, we also validated AlphaEvolveâ€™s constructions for larger ğ¾to ensure consistency of the eval-
uatorâ€™s accuracy. Using this basic setup we report AlphaEvolveâ€™s results in Figure 16. For small ğ‘›up to
40 AlphaEvolveâ€™s constructions might appear comparable in magnitude to some prior results in the literature
(e.g. [225]); however, for larger ğ‘›the performance deteriorates. Additionally, we observe a wider variation in
AlphaEvolveâ€™s scores which does not imply a definitive convergence as ğ‘›becomes larger. A few examples of
AlphaEvolve programs are provided in the Repository of Problems - in many instances the obtained programs
generate the sequence of coefficients using a mutation search process with heuristics on how to sample and pro-
duce the next iteration of the search. As a next step we will continue this exploration with additional methods to
guide AlphaEvolve towards better constructions and generalization of the polynomial sequences.
14. Blocks Stacking. To test AlphaEvolveâ€™s ability to obtain a general solution from special cases, we evalu-
ated its performance on the classic â€œblock-stacking problemâ€, also known as the â€œLeaning Tower of Lireâ€. See
Figure 17 for a depiction of the problem.
Problem 6.29 (Blocks stacking problem). Let ğ‘›â‰¥1. Let ğ¶6.29(ğ‘›) be the largest displacement that the ğ‘›th block
in a stack of identical rigid rectangular blocks of width 1 can be displaced horizontally over the edge of a table,
with the stack remaining stable. More mathematically, ğ¶6.29(ğ‘›) is the supremum of ğ‘¥ğ‘›where 0 = ğ‘¥0 â‰¤ğ‘¥1 â‰¤
â‹¯â‰¤ğ‘¥ğ‘›are real numbers subject to the constraints
ğ‘¥ğ‘–+1 + â‹¯+ ğ‘¥ğ‘›
ğ‘›âˆ’ğ‘–
< ğ‘¥ğ‘–+ 1
2
for all 0 â‰¤ğ‘–< ğ‘›. What is ğ¶6.29(ğ‘›)?
Block 5
Block 4
Block 3
Block 2
Block 1
1
2
1
4
1
6
1
8
1
10
Total Overhang = 1
2ğ»ğ‘›
FIGURE 17. A stack of ğ‘›= 5 blocks arranged to achieve maximum overhang.


--- Page 39 ---
39
It is well known that ğ¶6.29(ğ‘›) = 1
2ğ»ğ‘›, where ğ»ğ‘›= 1 + 1
2 + â‹¯+ 1
ğ‘›is the ğ‘›th harmonic number. Although
well-known in the literature, one could test variants and prompting that obfuscates much of the context. For
example, we prompted AlphaEvolve to produce a function that for a given integer input ğ‘›outputs a sequence of
real numbers (represented as an array positions[]) that optimizes a scoring function computing the following:
def get_positions_score(positions: list[float]) -> float:
"""Calculates the score of given points."""
n = len(positions)
if n == 0:
return 0.0
if n == 1:
if positions[0] - 0.5 >= 0.0 - FLOAT_TOLERANCE:
return -1.0
return positions[0]
sum_all = 0.0
for k in range(n):
sum_all += (positions[k] - 0.5)
sum_all_avg = sum_all / n
if sum_all_avg >= 0.0 - FLOAT_TOLERANCE:
return -1.0
upper_sum = 0.0
upper_count = 0.0
if n > 1:
upper_sum = positions[n-1] - 0.5
upper_count = 1
for i in range(n - 2, -1, -1):
upper_sum_avg = upper_sum / upper_count
lb = positions[i] - 1.0
ub = positions[i]
if not (lb - FLOAT_TOLERANCE <= upper_sum_avg <= ub + FLOAT_TOLERANCE):
return -1.0
upper_sum += (positions[i] - 0.5)
upper_count += 1.0
return positions[-1]
Using our generalizer mode after one or two iterations AlphaEvolve produced the correct form of the solution.
The suggestion was based on the following argumentation from the LLM that produces the recursive relation:
The optimal strategy involves setting the second iterative constraint to its tightest
possible valid equality for positions[i], which is:
positions[i] = upper_sum_avg for i = n-2, ..., 0.
This simplifies the constraint positions[i] - 1.0 <= positions[i] <= positions[i]
to -1.0 <= 0 and 0 <= 0, which is always true.
Let $P = positions[n-1]$. We define $x_k = positions[k] - P$. This implies $x_{n-1} = 0$.
Substituting positions[k] = P + x_k into the equality positions[i] = upper_sum_avg, we get
a recurrence relation for $x_k$:
$x_i = \left(\sum_{j=i+1}^{n-1} x_j\right) / (n - i - 1) - 0.5$, for $i = n-2, \dots, 0$.
We can calculate all $x_k$ values working backwards from $x_{n-1}=0$.
Once all $x_k$ are determined, we need to find the optimal value for $P$.
The constraints on $P$ are:
*
P + x_k > 0 for all $k$. This implies $P > \max_{k} (-x_k)$.
Let $P_{lower_bound} = \max(0.0, \max_k (-x_k))$.
*
$n \cdot (P - 0.5) + \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} x_k < 0.0 - n \cdot \text{FLOAT_TOLERANCE} / 2$


--- Page 40 ---
40
(to satisfy the strict inequality).
This implies $P < 0.5 - \left(\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} x_k\right) / n - \text{FLOAT_TOLERANCE} / 2$.
Let $P_{upper_bound_target} = 0.5 - \left(\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} x_k\right) / n$.
To maximize $P$, we choose $P = P_{upper_bound_target} - \delta$, where $\delta$ is a small
positive value chosen to satisfy the strict inequality
(sum_all_avg < 0.0 - FLOAT_TOLERANCE). By setting sum_all_avg = -2 * FLOAT_TOLERANCE, we
ensure this condition is met. Thus, we pick $\delta = 2 \cdot \text{FLOAT_TOLERANCE}$.
The corresponding AlphaEvolve suggestion is:
def get_positions(n: int) -> list[float]:
if n == 0:
return []
x_values = [0.0] * n
current_sum_x_suffix = 0.0
for i in range(n - 2, -1, -1):
count_suffix = n - 1 - i
x_values[i] = current_sum_x_suffix / count_suffix - 0.5
current_sum_x_suffix += x_values[i]
total_x_sum = current_sum_x_suffix
P_upper_bound_target = 0.5 - total_x_sum / n
P = P_upper_bound_target - 2 * FLOAT_TOLERANCE
P_lower_bound = 0.0
for x_val in x_values:
P_lower_bound = max(P_lower_bound, -x_val)
if P <= P_lower_bound + FLOAT_TOLERANCE:
P = max(P, P_lower_bound + 2 * FLOAT_TOLERANCE)
positions = [(P + x_val) for x_val in x_values]
return positions
In conclusion, at the next iteration AlphaEvolve refines the readability by arguing:
The current program implements a sophisticated algorithm leveraging
harmonic numbers to construct the list of positions.
My analysis confirms that this approach,
which sets positions[k] = 0.5 * (H_n - H_{n-k-1}) - 2 * FLOAT_TOLERANCE,
correctly satisfies all constraints of the get_positions_score function.
and produces the program:
def get_positions(n: int) -> list[float]:
if n == 0:
return []
harmonic_numbers = [0.0] * (n + 1)
for j in range(1, n + 1):
harmonic_numbers[j] = harmonic_numbers[j-1] + 1.0 / j
q_values = [0.0] * n


--- Page 41 ---
41
for k in range(n):
q_values[k] = 0.5 * (harmonic_numbers[n] - harmonic_numbers[n - k - 1]) - 0.5 - 2 * FLOAT_TOLERANCE
positions = [q + 0.5 for q in q_values]
return positions
15. The arithmetic Kakeya conjecture.
Problem 6.30 (Arithmetic Kakeya conjecture). For each slope ğ‘Ÿâˆˆâ„âˆª{âˆ} define the projection ğœ‹ğ‘Ÿâˆ¶â„2 â†’
â„by ğœ‹ğ‘Ÿ(ğ‘, ğ‘) = ğ‘+ ğ‘Ÿğ‘for ğ‘Ÿâ‰ âˆand ğœ‹âˆ(ğ‘, ğ‘) = ğ‘. Given a set ğ‘Ÿ1, â€¦ , ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜, ğ‘Ÿâˆof distinct slopes, we let
ğ¶6.30({ğ‘Ÿ1, â€¦ , ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜}; ğ‘Ÿâˆ) be the smallest constant for which the following is true: if ğ‘‹, ğ‘Œare discrete random
variables (not necessarily independent) taking values in a finite set of reals, then
ğ‡(ğœ‹ğ‘Ÿâˆ(ğ‘‹, ğ‘Œ)) â‰¤ğ¶6.30({ğ‘Ÿ1, â€¦ , ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜}; ğ‘Ÿâˆ) max
ğ‘–=1,â€¦,ğ‘˜ğ‡(ğœ‹ğ‘Ÿğ‘–(ğ‘‹, ğ‘Œ)),
where ğ‡(ğ‘‹) = âˆ’âˆ‘
ğ‘¥ğ‘ƒ(ğ‘‹= ğ‘¥) log(ğ‘ƒ(ğ‘‹= ğ‘¥)) is the entropy of a random variable and ğ‘¥ranges over the values
taken by ğ‘‹. The arithmetic Kakeya conjecture asserts that ğ¶6.30({ğ‘Ÿ1, â€¦ , ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜}; ğ‘Ÿâˆ) can be made arbitrarily close
to 1.
Note that one can let ğ‘‹, ğ‘Œtake rationals or integers without loss of generality.
There are several further equivalent ways to define these constants: see [151]. In the literature it is common to
use projective invariance to normalize ğ‘Ÿâˆ= âˆ’1, and also to require the projection ğœ‹ğ‘Ÿâˆto be injective on the
support of (ğ‘‹, ğ‘Œ). It is known that
1.77898 â‰¤ğ¶6.30({0, 1, âˆ}; âˆ’1) â‰¤11âˆ•6 = 1.833 â€¦
and
1.61226 â‰¤ğ¶6.30({0, 1, 2, âˆ}; âˆ’1) â‰¤7âˆ•4 = 1.75,
with the upper bounds established in [174] and the lower bounds in [194]. Further upper bounds on various
ğ¶6.30({ğ‘Ÿ1, â€¦ , ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜}; ğ‘Ÿâˆ) were obtained in [173], with the infimal such bound being about 1.6751 (the largest root
of ğ›¼3 âˆ’4ğ›¼+ 2 = 0).
One can obtain lower bounds on ğ¶6.30({ğ‘Ÿ1, â€¦ , ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜}; ğ‘Ÿâˆ) for specific ğ‘Ÿ1, â€¦ , ğ‘Ÿğ‘˜, ğ‘Ÿâˆby exhibiting specific discrete
random variables ğ‘‹, ğ‘Œ. AlphaEvolve managed to improve the first bound only in the eighth decimal, but
got the more interesting improvement of 1.668 â‰¤ğ¶6.30({0, 1, 2, âˆ}; âˆ’1) for the second one. Afterwards we
asked AlphaEvolve to write parametrized code that solves the problem for hundreds of different sets of slopes
simultaneously, hoping to get some insights about the general solution. The joint distributions of the random
variables ğ‘‹, ğ‘Œgenerated by AlphaEvolve resembled discrete Gaussians, see Figure 18. Inspired by the form of
the AlphaEvolve results, we were able to establish rigorously an asymptotic for ğ¶6.30({0, 1, âˆ}; ğ‘ ) for rational
ğ‘ â‰ 0, 1, âˆ, and specifically that6
2 âˆ’
ğ‘2
log(2 + |ğ‘| + |ğ‘|) â‰¤ğ¶6.30
(
{0, 1, âˆ}; ğ‘
ğ‘
)
â‰¤2 âˆ’
ğ‘1
log(2 + |ğ‘| + |ğ‘|)
for some absolute constants ğ‘2 > ğ‘1 > 0, whenever ğ‘is a positive integer and ğ‘is coprime to ğ‘; this and other
related results will appear in forthcoming work of the third author [282].
16. Furstenbergâ€“SÃ¡rkÃ¶zy theorem.
Problem 6.31 (Furstenbergâ€“SÃ¡rkÃ¶zy problem). If ğ‘˜, ğ‘šâ‰¥2 and ğ‘â‰¥1, let ğ¶6.31(ğ‘˜, ğ‘) (resp. ğ¶6.31(ğ‘˜, â„¤âˆ•ğ‘€â„¤))
denote the size of the largest subset of {1, â€¦ , ğ‘} that does not contain any two elements that differ by a perfect
ğ‘˜th power. Establish upper and lower bounds for ğ¶6.31(ğ‘˜, ğ‘) and ğ¶6.31(ğ‘˜, â„¤âˆ•ğ‘€â„¤) that are as strong as possible.
6The lower bound here was directly inspired by the AlphaEvolve constructions; the upper bound was then guessed to be true, and proven
using existing methods in the literature (based on the Shannon entropy inequalities).


--- Page 42 ---
42
FIGURE 18. Examples for various slope combinations found by AlphaEvolve. From left
to right: ğ¶6.30({0, 3âˆ•7, âˆ}; âˆ’1)), ğ¶6.30({0, 1, 2, âˆ}; 7âˆ•4), ğ¶6.30({0, 13âˆ•19, âˆ}; âˆ’1)) rescaled,
ğ¶6.30({0, 1, 2, âˆ}; 27âˆ•23) rescaled.
Trivially one has ğ¶6.31(ğ‘˜, â„¤âˆ•ğ‘€â„¤) â‰¤ğ¶6.31(ğ‘˜, ğ‘€). The Furstenbergâ€“SÃ¡rkÃ¶zy theorem [136], [247] shows that
ğ¶6.31(ğ‘˜, ğ‘) = ğ‘œ(ğ‘) as ğ‘â†’âˆfor any fixed ğ‘˜, and hence also ğ¶6.31(ğ‘˜, â„¤âˆ•ğ‘€â„¤) = ğ‘œ(ğ‘€) as ğ‘€â†’âˆ. The most
studied case is ğ‘˜= 2, where there is a recent bound
ğ¶6.31(ğ‘˜, ğ‘) â‰²ğ‘exp(âˆ’ğ‘
âˆš
log ğ‘)
due to Green and Sawhney [152].
The best known asymptotic lower bounds for ğ¶6.31(ğ‘˜, ğ‘) come from the inequality
ğ¶6.31(ğ‘˜, ğ‘) â‰³ğ‘
1âˆ’1
ğ‘˜+ log ğ¶6.31(ğ‘˜,â„¤âˆ•ğ‘šâ„¤)
ğ‘˜log ğ‘š
âˆ’ğ‘œ(1)
for any ğ‘˜, ğ‘, and square-free ğ‘š; see [196, 245]. One can thus establish lower bounds for ğ¶6.31(ğ‘˜, ğ‘) by exhibiting

differences, aiming to improve the lower bounds for ğ¶6.31(2, ğ‘) and ğ¶6.31(3, ğ‘). AlphaEvolve managed to
quickly reproduce the known lower bounds for both of these constants using the same moduli (205 and 91), but
it did not find anything better.
17. Spherical designs.
Problem 6.32 (Spherical designs). A spherical ğ‘¡-design7 on the ğ‘‘-dimensional sphere ğ‘†ğ‘‘âŠ‚â„ğ‘‘+1 is a finite set
of points ğ‘‹âŠ‚ğ‘†ğ‘‘such that for any polynomial ğ‘ƒof degree at most ğ‘¡, the average value of ğ‘ƒover ğ‘‹is equal to
the average value of ğ‘ƒover the entire sphere ğ‘†ğ‘‘. For each ğ‘¡âˆˆâ„•, let ğ¶6.32(ğ‘‘, ğ‘¡) be the minimal number of points
in a spherical ğ‘¡-design. Establish upper and lower bounds on ğ¶6.32(ğ‘‘, ğ‘¡) that are as strong as possible.
The following lower bounds for ğ¶6.32(ğ‘‘, ğ‘¡) were proved by Delsarteâ€“Goethalsâ€“Seidel [91]:
ğ¶6.32(ğ‘‘, ğ‘¡) â‰¥
(

for ğ‘¡= 2ğ‘˜

)
for ğ‘¡= 2ğ‘˜+ 1
7We thank Joaquim Ortega-CerdÃ  for suggesting this problem to us.


--- Page 43 ---
43
Designs that meet these bounds are called â€œtightâ€ spherical designs and are known to be rare. Only eight tight
spherical designs are known for ğ‘‘â‰¥2 and ğ‘¡â‰¥4, and all of them are obtained from lattices. Moreover, the
construction of spherical ğ‘¡-designs for fixed ğ‘‘and ğ‘¡â†’âˆbecomes challenging even in the case ğ‘‘= 2.
There is a strong relationship [246] between Problem 6.32 and the Thomson problem (see Problem 6.33 below).
The task of upper bounding ğ¶6.32(ğ‘‘, ğ‘¡) amounts to specifying a finite configuration and is thus a potential use
case for AlphaEvolve. The existence of spherical ğ‘¡-designs with ğ‘‚(ğ‘¡ğ‘‘) points was conjectured by Korevaar
and Meyers [186] and later proven by Bondarenko, Radchenko, and Viazovska [37]. We point the reader to the
survey of Cohn [64] and to the online database [264] for the most recent bounds on ğ¶6.32(ğ‘‘, ğ‘¡).

We accepted a configuration if the error was below 10âˆ’8. AlphaEvolve was able to find the ğ¶6.32(1, ğ‘¡) = ğ‘¡+1 con-
structions instantly. Besides this sanity check, AlphaEvolve was able to obtain constructions for ğ¶6.32(2, 19) and
ğ¶6.32(2, 21) of sizes 198, 200, 202, 204 for the former, and 234, 236 for the latter. Those constructions improved
on the literature bounds [264]. It also found constructions for ğ¶6.32(2, 15) of the new sizes 122, 124, 126, 128, 130.
Those constructions did not improve on the literature bounds but they are new.


--- Page 44 ---
44
We note that these constructions only yield a (high precision) solution candidate. A natural next step could be
that once a candidate is found, one can write code (e.g using Arb [171]/FLINT [162] 8) that is also able to certify
that there is a solution near the approximation using a fixed point method and a computer-assisted proof. We
leave this to future work.
18. The Thomson and Tammes problems. The Thomson problem [285, p. 255] asks for the minimal-energy
configuration of ğ‘classical electrons confined to the unit sphere ğ•Š2. This is also related to Smaleâ€™s 7th problem
[266].
Problem 6.33 (Thomson problem). For any ğ‘> 1, let ğ¶6.33(ğ‘) denote the infimum of the Coulomb energy
ğ¸6.33(ğ‘§1, â€¦ , ğ‘§ğ‘) âˆ¶=
âˆ‘
1â‰¤ğ‘–<ğ‘—â‰¤ğ‘
1
â€–ğ‘§ğ‘–âˆ’ğ‘§ğ‘—â€–
where ğ‘§1, â€¦ , ğ‘§ğ‘range over the unit sphere ğ•Š2. Establish upper and lower bounds on ğ¶6.33(ğ‘) that are as strong
as possible. What type of configurations ğ‘§1, â€¦ , ğ‘§ğ‘come close to achieving the infimal (ground state) energy?
One could consider other potential energy functions than the Coulomb potential
1
â€–ğ‘§ğ‘–âˆ’ğ‘§ğ‘—â€–, but we restricted atten-
tion here to the classical Coulomb case for ease of comparison with the literature.
The survey [14] and the website [15] contain a report on massive computer experiments and detailed tables with
optimizers up to ğ‘›= 64. Further benchmarks (e.g. [191]) go up to ğ‘›= 204 and beyond. There is a large
literature on Thomsonâ€™s problem, starting from the work of Cohn [63]. The precise value of ğ¶6.33(ğ‘) is known
for ğ‘= 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 12. The cases ğ‘= 4, 6 were proved by Yudin [305], ğ‘= 5 by Schwartz [255] using a
computer-assisted proof, and ğ‘= 12 by Cohn and Kumar [67].
In the asymptotic regime ğ‘â†’âˆ, it is easy to extract the leading order term ğ¶6.33(ğ‘) = ( 1
2 + ğ‘œ(1))ğ‘2, coming
from the bulk electrostatic energy; this was refined by Wagner [292, 293] to
ğ¶6.33(ğ‘) = 1
2ğ‘2 + ğ‘‚(ğ‘3âˆ•2).
Erberâ€“Hockney [102] and Glasserâ€“Every [141] computed numerically the energies for a finite amount of val-
ues of ğ‘and fitted their data, to ğ‘2âˆ•2 âˆ’0.5510ğ‘3âˆ•2 and ğ‘2âˆ•2 âˆ’0.55195ğ‘3âˆ•2 + 0.05025ğ‘1âˆ•2 respectively.
Rakhmanovâ€“Saffâ€“Zhou [234] fit their data to ğ‘2âˆ•2âˆ’0.55230ğ‘3âˆ•2+0.0689ğ‘1âˆ•2 but also made the more precise
conjecture
ğ¶6.33(ğ‘) = 1
2ğ‘2 + ğµğ‘3âˆ•2 + ğ¶ğ‘1âˆ•2 + ğ‘‚(ğ‘âˆ’1âˆ•2),
which, if true, implied the bound âˆ’3
2 â‰¤ğµâ‰¤âˆ’
1
4
âˆš
2ğœ‹. Kuijlaarsâ€“Saff [246] conjectured that the constant ğµis
equal to 3
( âˆš

)1âˆ•2
ğœ(1âˆ•2)ğ¿âˆ’3(1âˆ•2) â‰ˆâˆ’0.5530 â€¦, where ğ¿âˆ’3 is a Dirichlet ğ¿-function.
We ran AlphaEvolve in our default search framework on values of ğ‘up to 300, where the scoring function is
given by the energy functional ğ¸6.33, thus obtaining upper bounds on ğ¶6.33(ğ‘). In the prompt we only instruct
AlphaEvolve to search for the positions of points that optimize the above energy ğ¸6.33 - in particular, no further
hints are given (e.g. regarding a preferred optimization scheme or patterns in the points). For lower values of
ğ‘< 50, AlphaEvolve was able to match the results reported in [191] up to an accuracy of 10âˆ’8 within the first
hour; larger values of ğ‘required ğ‘‚(10) hours to reach this saturation point. An excerpt of the obtained energies
is given in Table 4.

Additionally, we explored some of our generalization methods whereby we prompt AlphaEvolve to focus on
producing fast, short and readable programs. Our evaluation tested the proposed constructions on different
values of ğ‘up to 500 - more specifically, the scoring function took the average of the energies obtained for
ğ‘= 4, 5, 8, 10, 12, 16, 18, 25, 32, 33, 64, 70, 100, 150, 200, 250, 300, 350, 400, 450, 500. In most cases the ob-
tained evolved programs were based on heuristics from small configurations, uniform sampling on the sphere
followed by a few-step refinement (e.g. by gradient descent or stochastic perturbation) - we note that although
the programs demonstrate reasonable runtime performance, their formal analysis regarding asymptotic behavior
is non-trivial due to the optimization component (e.g. gradient descent). A few examples are provided in the
Repository of Problems . An illustration of some of AlphaEvolveâ€™s programs is given in Figure 20. As a next
step we attempt to extract tighter bounds on the lower order coefficients in the energy asymptotics expansion in
ğ‘(work in progress).
A variant of the Thomson problem (formally corresponding to potentials of the form
1
â€–ğ‘§ğ‘–âˆ’ğ‘§ğ‘—â€–ğ›¼in the limit ğ›¼â†’âˆ)
is the Tammes problem [277].
Problem 6.34 (Tammes problem). For ğ‘â‰¥2, let ğ¶6.34(ğ‘) denote the maximal value of the energy
ğ¸6.34(ğ‘§1, â€¦ , ğ‘§ğ‘) âˆ¶=
min
1â‰¤ğ‘–<ğ‘—â‰¤ğ‘â€–ğ‘§ğ‘–âˆ’ğ‘§ğ‘—â€–
where ğ‘§1, â€¦ , ğ‘§ğ‘range over points in ğ•Š2. Establish upper and lower bounds on ğ¶6.34(ğ‘) that are as strong as
possible. What type of configurations ğ‘§1, â€¦ , ğ‘§ğ‘come close to achieving the maximal energy?

3, 7, 12) the constructions match the theoretically known best results ([263]); additionally, we
give an illustration of the performance for larger ğ‘.
One can interpret the Tammes problem in terms of spherical codes: ğ¶6.34(ğ‘) is the largest quantity for which
one can pack ğ‘disks of (Euclidean) diameter ğ¶6.34(ğ‘) in the unit sphere. The Tammes problem has been solved
for ğ‘= 3, 4, 6, 12 by Fejes TÃ³th [286]; for ğ‘= 5, 7, 8, 9 by SchÃ¼tteâ€“van der Waerden [254]; for ğ‘= 10, 11
by Danzer [86]; for ğ‘= 13, 14 by Musinâ€“Tarasov [217, 219]; and for ğ‘= 24 by Robinson [241]. See also the
websites [65], maintained by Henry Cohn, and [263] maintained by Neil Sloane.
It should be noted that this problem has been used as a benchmark for optimization techniques due to being NP-
hard [93] and the fact that the number of locally optimal solutions increases exponentially with the number of
points. See [189] for recent numerical results.
Similarly to the Thomson problem, we applied AlphaEvolve with our search mode. The scoring function was
given by the energy ğ¸6.34. For small ğ‘where the best configurations are theoretically known AlphaEvolve
was able to match those - an illustration of the scores we obtain after ğ‘‚(10) hours of iterations can be found in
Table 5. A feature of the AlphaEvolve search mode here is that the structure of the evolved programs often
consisted of case-by-case checking for some given small values of ğ‘followed by an optimization procedure -
depending on the search time we allowed, the optimization procedures could lead to obscure or long programs;
one strategy to mitigate those effects was via prompting hints towards shorter optimization patterns or shorter
search time (some examples are provided in the Repository of Problems ).
19. Packing problems.


--- Page 47 ---
47
FIGURE 21. The Tammes problem: examples of constructions for t obtained by AlphaEvolve:
(left) the case of ğ‘›= 12 recovering the theoretically optimal icosahedron and (right) the case
of ğ‘›= 50.
Problem 6.35 (Packing in a dilate). For any ğ‘›â‰¥1 and a geometric shape ğ‘ƒ(e.g. a polygon, a polytope or a
sphere), let ğ¶6.35(ğ‘›, ğ‘ƒ) denote the smallest scale ğ‘ such that one can place ğ‘›identical copies of ğ‘ƒwith disjoint
interiors inside another copy of ğ‘ƒscaled up by a factor of ğ‘ . Establish lower and upper bounds for ğ¶6.35(ğ‘›, ğ‘ƒ)
that are as strong as possible.
Many classical problems fall into this category. For example, what is the smallest square into which one can
pack ğ‘›unit squares? This problem and many different variants of it are discussed in e.g. [131, 126, 176, 112].
We selected dozens of different ğ‘›and ğ‘ƒin two and three dimensions and tasked AlphaEvolve to produce upper
bounds on ğ¶6.35(ğ‘›, ğ‘ƒ). Given an arrangement of copies of ğ‘ƒ, if any two of them intersected we gave a big
penalty proportional to their intersection, ensuring that the penalty function was chosen such that any locally
optimal configuration cannot contain intersecting pairs. The smallest scale of a bounding ğ‘ƒwas computed
via binary search, where we always assumed it would have a fixed orientation. The final score was given by
ğ‘ + âˆ‘
ğ‘–,ğ‘—Area(ğ‘ƒğ‘–âˆ©ğ‘ƒğ‘—): the scale ğ‘ plus the penalty, which we wanted to minimize.
In the case when ğ‘ƒis a hexagon, we managed to improve the best results for ğ‘›= 11 and ğ‘›= 12 respectively,
improving on the results reported in [126]. See Figure 22 for a depiction of the new optima. These packings were
then analyzed and refined by Johann Schellhorn [249], who pointed out to us that surprisingly, AlphaEvolve did
not make the final construction completely symmetric. This is a good example to show that one should not take
it for granted that AlphaEvolve will figure out all the ideas that are â€œobviousâ€ for humans, and that a human-AI
collaboration is often the best way to solve problems.
In the case when ğ‘ƒis a cube [0, 1]3, the current world records may be found in [134]. In particular, for ğ‘›< 34,
the non-trivial arrangements known correspond to the cases 9 â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤14 and 28 â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤33. AlphaEvolve was
able to match the arrangements for ğ‘›= 9, 10, 12 and beat the one for ğ‘›= 11, improving the upper bound for
ğ¶6.35(11, ğ‘ƒ) from 2 +
âˆš
8âˆ•5 +
âˆš
3âˆ•5 â‰ˆ2.912096 to 2.894531. Figure 23 depicts the current new optimum for
ğ‘›= 11 (see also Repository of Problems ). It can likely still be improved slightly by manual analysis, as in the
hexagon case.
Problem 6.36 (Circle packing in a square). For any ğ‘›â‰¥1, let ğ¶6.36(ğ‘›) denote the largest sum âˆ‘ğ‘›
ğ‘–=1 ğ‘Ÿğ‘–of radii
such that one can place ğ‘›disjoint open disks of radius ğ‘Ÿ1, â€¦ , ğ‘Ÿğ‘›inside the unit square, and let ğ¶â€²
6.36(ğ‘›) denote the
largest sum âˆ‘ğ‘›
ğ‘–=1 ğ‘Ÿğ‘–of radii such that one can place ğ‘›disjoint open disks of radius ğ‘Ÿ1, â€¦ , ğ‘Ÿğ‘›inside a rectangle
of perimeter 4. Establish upper and lower bounds for ğ¶6.36(ğ‘›) and ğ¶â€²
6.36(ğ‘›) that are as strong as possible.


--- Page 48 ---
48
FIGURE 22. Constructions of the packing problems found by AlphaEvolve. Left: Packing
11 unit hexagons into a regular hexagon of side length 3.931. Right: Packing 12 unit hexagons
into a regular hexagon of side length 3.942. Image reproduced from [224].
FIGURE 23. Packing 11 unit cubes into a bigger cube of side length â‰ˆ2.895.
Clearly ğ¶6.36(ğ‘›) â‰¤ğ¶â€²
6.36(ğ‘›). Existing upper bounds on these quantities may be found at [129, 128]. In our initial
work, AlphaEvolve found new constructions improving these bounds. To adhere to the three-digit precision
established in [129, 128], our publication presented a simplified construction with truncated values, sufficient to
secure an improvement in the third decimal place. Subsequent work [25, 94] has since refined our published con-
struction, extending its numerical precision in the later decimal places. As this demonstrates, the problem allows
for continued numerical refinement, where further gains are largely a function of computational investment. A
brief subsequent experiment with AlphaEvolve readily produced a new construction that surpasses these recent
bounds; we provide full-precision constructions in the Repository of Problems .
20. The TurÃ¡n number of the tetrahedron. An 80-year old open problem in extremal hypergraph theory is
the TurÃ¡n hypergraph problem. Here ğ¾(3)
4
stands for the complete 3-uniform hypergraph on 4 vertices.
Problem 6.37 (TurÃ¡n hypergraph problem for the tetrahedron). Let ğ¶6.37 be the largest quantity such that,
as ğ‘›â†’âˆ, one can locate a 3-uniform hypergraph on ğ‘›vertices and at least (ğ¶6.37 âˆ’ğ‘œ(1))(ğ‘›
3

no copy of the tetrahedron ğ¾(3)
4 . What is ğ¶6.37?
It is known that

with the upper bound obtained by Razborov [236] using flag algebra methods. It is conjectured that the lower

Although the constant ğ¶6.37 is defined asymptotically in nature, one can easily obtain a lower bound
ğ¶6.37 â‰¥

the lower bound are also known [187].
While it was a long shot, we attempted to find a better lower bound for ğ¶6.37. We ran AlphaEvolve with
ğ‘›= 10, 15, 20, 25, 30 with its standard search mode. It quickly discovered the 5âˆ•9 construction typically within
one evolution step, but beyond that, it did not find any better constructions.
21. Factoring ğ‘! into ğ‘numbers.
Problem 6.38 (Factoring factorials). For a natural number ğ‘, let ğ¶6.38(ğ‘) be the largest quantity such that
ğ‘! can be factored into ğ‘factors that are greater than or equal to ğ¶6.38(ğ‘)9. Establish upper and lower bounds
on ğ¶6.38(ğ‘) that are as strong as possible.
Among other results, it was shown in [5] that asymptotically,
ğ¶6.38(ğ‘)
ğ‘
= 1
ğ‘’âˆ’
ğ‘0
log ğ‘+ ğ‘‚
(
1
log1+ğ‘ğ‘
)
for certain explicit constants ğ‘0, ğ‘> 0, answering questions of ErdÅ‘s, Guy, and Selfridge.
After obtaining the prime factorizations, computing ğ¶6.38(ğ‘) exactly is a special case of the bin covering prob-
lem, which is NP-hard in general. However, the special nature of the factorial function ğ‘! renders the task
of computing ğ¶6.38(ğ‘) relatively feasible for small ğ‘, with techniques such as linear programming or greedy
algorithms being remarkably effective at providing good upper and lower bounds for ğ¶6.38(ğ‘). Exact val-
ues of ğ¶6.38(ğ‘) for ğ‘â‰¤104, as well as several upper and lower bounds for larger ğ‘, may be found at
https://github.com/teorth/erdos-guy-selfridge.
9See https://oeis.org/A034258.


--- Page 50 ---
50
Lower bounds for ğ¶6.38(ğ‘) can of course be obtained simply by exhibiting a suitable factorization of ğ‘!. After
the release of the first version of [5], Andrew Sutherland posted his code at https://math.mit.edu/~drew/
GuySelfridge.m and we used it as a benchmark. Specifically we tried the following setups:
(1) Vanilla AlphaEvolve, no hints;
(2) AlphaEvolve could use Sutherlandâ€™s code as a blackbox to get a good initial partition;
(3) AlphaEvolve could use and modify the code in any way it wanted.
In the first setup, AlphaEvolve came up with various elaborate greedy methods, but not Sutherlandâ€™s algorithm
by itself. Its top choice was a complex variant of the simple approach where a random number was moved
from the largest group to the smallest. For large ğ‘›using Sutherlandâ€™s code as additional information helped,
though we did not see big differences between using it as a blackbox or allowing it to be modified. In both cases
AlphaEvolve used it once to get a good initial partition, and then never used it again.
We tested it by running it for 80 â‰¤ğ‘â‰¤600 and it improved in several instances (see Table 6), matching on all
the others (which is expected since by definition AlphaEvolveâ€™s setup starts at the benchmark).

optimal value that was certified by integer programming.
22. Beat the average game.
Problem 6.39 (Beat the average game). Let ğ¶6.39 denote the quantity
ğ¶6.39 âˆ¶= sup
ğœ‡
â„™[ğ‘‹1 + ğ‘‹2 + ğ‘‹3 < 2ğ‘‹4]
where ğœ‡ranges over probability measures on [0, âˆ) and let ğ‘‹1, â€¦ , ğ‘‹4 âˆ¼ğœ‡are independent random variables
with law ğœ‡. Establish upper and lower bounds on ğ¶6.39 that are as strong as possible.
Problem 6.39, a generalization of the case with two variables on the left-hand side, was recently discussed
in [209]. For about six months the best lower bound for ğ¶6.39 was 0.367. Later, Bellec and Fritz [21] estab-
lished bounds of 0.400695 â‰¤ğ¶6.39 â‰¤0.417, with the upper bound obtained via linear programming methods.
The main idea to get lower bounds for ğ¶6.39 is to construct the optimal ğœ‡approximating it by a discrete probability
ğœ‡= âˆ‘ğ‘
ğ‘–=1 ğ‘ğ‘–ğ›¿ğ‘–and, after rewriting the desired probability as a convolution, optimizing over the ğ‘ğ‘–. We were able


--- Page 51 ---
51
to obtain, with the most straightforward possible AlphaEvolve setup and no expert hints, within only a few
hours of running AlphaEvolve, the lower bound ğ¶6.39 â‰¥0.389. This demonstrates the value of this method. It
shows that in the short amount of time required to set up the experiment, AlphaEvolve can generate competitive
(contemporaneous state of the art) outputs. This suggests that such tools are highly effective for potentially
generating strong initial conjectures and guiding more focused, subsequent analytical work. While this bound
does not outperform the final results of [21], it was evident from AlphaEvolveâ€™s constructions that optimal
discrete measures appeared to be sparse (most of the ğ‘ğ‘–were 0), and the non-zero values were distributed in a
particular pattern. A human mathematician could look at these constructions and get insights from it, leading to
a human-written proof of a better lower bound.
23. ErdÅ‘s discrepancy problem.
Problem 6.40 (ErdÅ‘s discrepancy problem). The discrepancy of a sign pattern ğ‘1, â€¦ , ğ‘ğ‘âˆˆ{âˆ’1, +1} is the
maximum value of |ğ‘ğ‘‘+ ğ‘2ğ‘‘+ â‹¯+ ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘‘| for homogeneous progressions ğ‘‘, â€¦ , ğ‘˜ğ‘‘in {1, â€¦ , ğ‘}. For any ğ·â‰¥1,
let ğ¶6.40(ğ·) denote the largest ğ‘for which there exists a sign pattern ğ‘1, â€¦ , ğ‘ğ‘of discrepancy at most ğ¶.
Establish upper and lower bounds on ğ¶6.40(ğ·) that are as strong as possible.
It is known that ğ¶6.40(0) = 0, ğ¶6.40(1) = 11, ğ¶6.40(2) = 1160, and ğ¶6.40(3) â‰¥13 000 [185]10, and that ğ¶6.40(ğ·)
is finite for any ğ·[280], the latter result answering a question of ErdÅ‘s [104]. Multiplicative sequences (in which
ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘š= ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘šfor ğ‘›, ğ‘šcoprime) tend to be reasonably good choices for low discrepancy sequences, though not
optimal; the longest multiplicative sequence of discrepancy 2 is of length 344 [185].
Lower bounds for ğ¶6.40(ğ·) can be generated by exhibiting a single sign pattern of discrepancy at most ğ·, so we
asked AlphaEvolve to generate a long sequence with discrepancy 2. The score was given by the length of the
longest initial sequence with discrepancy 2, plus a fractional score reflecting what proportion of the progressions
ending at the next point have too large discrepancy.
First, when we let AlphaEvolve attempt this problem with no human guidance, it found a sequence of length
200 before progress started to slow down. Next, in the prompt of a new experiment we gave it the advice to
try a function which is multiplicative, or approximately multiplicative. With this hint, AlphaEvolve performed
much better, and found constructions of length 380 in the same amount of time. Nevertheless, these attempts
were still far from the optimal value of 1160. It is possible that other hints, such as suggesting the use of SAT
solvers, could have improved the score further, but due to time limitations, we did not explore these directions in
the end.
24. Points on sphere maximizing the volume. In 1964, Fejesâ€“TÃ³th [121] proposed the following problem:
Problem 6.41 (Fejesâ€“TÃ³th problem). For any ğ‘›â‰¥4, Let ğ¶6.41(ğ‘›) denote the maximum volume of a polyhedron
with ğ‘›vertices that all lie on the unit sphere ğ•Š2. What is ğ¶6.41(ğ‘›)? Which polyhedra attain the maximum volume?
Bermanâ€“Hanes [24] found a necessary condition for optimal polyhedra, and found the optimal ones for ğ‘›â‰¤8.
Mutoh [220] found numerically candidates for the cases ğ‘›â‰¤30. HorvÃ¡thâ€“LÃ¡ngi [168] solved the problem in the
case of ğ‘‘+2 points in ğ‘‘dimensions and, additionally, ğ‘‘+3 whenever ğ‘‘is odd. See also the surveys [44, 81, 161]
for a more thorough description of this and related problems. The case ğ‘›> 8 remains open and the most up to
date database of current optimal polytopes is maintained by Sloane [262].
In our case, in order to maximize the volume, the loss function was set to be minus the volume of the polytope,
computed by decomposing the polytope into tetrahedra and summing their volumes. Using the standard search
mode of AlphaEvolve, we were able to quickly match the first approx. 60 results reported in [262] up to all 13
10see also https://oeis.org/A237695.


--- Page 52 ---
52
digits reported, and we did not manage to improve any of them. We did not attempt to improve the remaining
âˆ¼70 reported results.
25. Sums and differences problems. We tested AlphaEvolve against several open problems regarding the

finite sets of integers ğ´, ğµ.

later found a related set ğ‘ˆ2 of 54265 integers that further improves the lower bound to 1.1584 â‰¤ğ¶6.44, see [1]

of [158].
26. Sum-product problems. We tested AlphaEvolve against sum-product problems. An extensive bibliogra-
phy of work on this problem may be found at [33].
Problem 6.45 (Sum-product problem). Given a natural number ğ‘and a ring ğ‘…of size at least ğ‘, let ğ¶6.45(ğ‘…, ğ‘)
denote the least possible value of max(|ğ´+ ğ´|, |ğ´â‹…ğ´|) where ğ´ranges over subsets of ğ‘…of cardinality ğ‘. Es-

In the case of the integers â„¤, it is known that
ğ‘2âˆ’632

as ğ‘â†’âˆfor some constant ğ‘> 0, with the upper bound in [115] and the lower bound in [34]. It is a well-known

Another well-studied case is when ğ‘…is a finite field ğ…ğ‘of prime order, and we set ğ‘âˆ¶= âŒŠâˆšğ‘âŒ‹for concreteness.

We directed AlphaEvolve to upper bound ğ¶6.45(ğ…ğ‘, ğ‘) with ğ‘= âŒŠğ‘1âˆ•2âŒ‹. To encourage AlphaEvolve to find
a generalizable construction, we evaluated its programs on multiple primes. For each prime ğ‘we computed
log(max(|ğ´+ğ´|,|ğ´â‹…ğ´|))
log |ğ´|
and the final score was given by the average of these normalized scores. AlphaEvolve was
able to find ğ‘

2 sized constructions by intersecting certain arithmetic and geometric progressions. Interestingly,
in the regime ğ‘âˆ¼109, it was able to produce examples in which max(|ğ´+ ğ´|, |ğ´â‹…ğ´|) was slightly less than
ğ‘3âˆ•2. An analysis of the algorithm (provided by Deep Think) shows that the construction arose by first con-
structing finite sets ğ´â€² in the Gaussian integers â„¤[ğ‘–] with small sum set ğ´â€² + ğ´â€² and product set ğ´â€² â‹…ğ´â€², and
then projecting such sets to ğ…ğ‘(assuming ğ‘= 1 mod 4 so that one possessed a square root of âˆ’1). These sets


--- Page 54 ---
54
in turn were constructed as sets of Gaussian integers whose norm was bounded by a suitable bound ğ‘…2 (with
the specific choice ğ‘…= 3.2âŒŠ
âˆš
ğ‘˜âŒ‹+ 5 selected by AlphaEvolve), and also was smooth in the sense that the
largest prime factor of the norm was bounded by some threshold ğ¿(which AlphaEvolve selected by a greedy
algorithm, and in practice tended to take such values as 13 or 17). On further (human) analysis of the situation,
we believe that AlphaEvolve independently came up with a construction somewhat analogous to the smooth
integer construction originally used in [115] to establish the upper bound in (6.16), and that the fact that this
construction improved upon the exponent 3âˆ•2 was an artifact of the relatively small size ğ‘of ğ´(so that the
log log ğ‘denominator in (6.16) was small), combined with some minor features of the Gaussian integers (such
as the presence of the four units 1, âˆ’1, ğ‘–, âˆ’ğ‘–) that were favorable in this small size setting, but asymptotically
were of negligible importance. Our conclusion is that in cases where the asymptotic convergence is expected to
be slow (e.g., of double logarithmic nature), one should be cautious about mistaking asymptotic information for
concrete improvements at sizes not yet at the asymptotic scales, such as the evidence provided by AlphaEvolve
experiments.
27. Triangle density in graphs. As an experiment to see if AlphaEvolve could reconstruct known relation-
ships between subgraph densities, we tested it against the following problem.
Problem 6.46 (Minimal triangle density). For 0 â‰¤ğœŒâ‰¤1, let ğ¶6.46(ğœŒ) denote the largest quantity such that any
graph on ğ‘›vertices and (ğœŒ+ ğ‘œ(1))(ğ‘›
2
) edges will have at least (ğ¶6.46(ğœŒ) âˆ’ğ‘œ(1))(ğ‘›
3
) triangles. What is ğ¶6.46(ğœŒ)?
By considering (ğ‘¡+ 1)-partite graphs with ğ‘¡parts roughly equal, one can show that

While the problem concerns the asymptotic behavior as ğ‘›â†’âˆ, one can obtain upper bounds for ğ¶6.46(ğœŒ) for
a fixed ğœŒby starting with a fixed graph, blowing it up by a large factor, and deleting (asymptotically negligible)
loops. There are an uncountable number of values of ğœŒto consider; however, by deleting or adding edges we can
easily show the crude Lipschitz type bounds
ğ¶6.46(ğœŒ) â‰¤ğ¶6.46(ğœŒâ€²) â‰¤ğ¶6.46(ğœŒ) + 3(ğœŒâ€² âˆ’ğœŒ)
(6.18)
for all ğœŒâ‰¤ğœŒâ€² and so by specifying a finite number of graphs and applying the aforementioned blowup procedure,
one can obtain a piecewise linear upper bound for ğ¶6.46.
To get AlphaEvolve to find the solution for all values of ğœŒ, we set it up as follows. AlphaEvolve had to evolve
a function that returns a set of 100 step function graphons of rank 1, represented simply by lists of real numbers.
Because we expected that the task of finding partite graphs with mostly equal sizes to be too easy, we made it
more difficult by only telling AlphaEvolve that it has to find 100 lists containing real numbers, and we did not
tell it what exact problem it was trying to solve. For each of these graphons ğº1, â€¦ , ğº100, we calculated their edge
density ğœŒğ‘–and their triangle density ğ‘¡ğ‘–, to get 100 points ğ‘ğ‘–= (ğœŒğ‘–, ğ‘¡ğ‘–) âˆˆ[0, 1]2. Since the goal is to find ğ¶6.46(ğœŒ)
for all values of ğœŒ, i.e. for all ğœŒwe want to find the smallest feasible ğ‘¡, intuitively we need to ask AlphaEvolve
to minimize the area â€œbelow these pointsâ€. At first we ordered the points so that ğœŒğ‘–â‰¤ğœŒğ‘–+1 for all ğ‘–, connected the


--- Page 55 ---
55
FIGURE 25. Comparison between AlphaEvolveâ€™s set of 100 graphs and the optimal curve.
Left: at the start of the experiment, right: at the end of the experiment.
points ğ‘ğ‘–with straight lines, and the score of AlphaEvolve was the area under this piecewise linear curve, that
it had to minimize.
We quickly realized the mistake in our approach, when the area under AlphaEvolveâ€™s solution was smaller than
the area under the optimal (6.17) solution. The problem is that the area we are looking to find is not convex, so
if some points ğ‘ğ‘–and ğ‘ğ‘–+1 are in the feasible region for the problem, that doesnâ€™t mean that their midpoint is too.
AlphaEvolve figured out how to sample the 50 points in such a way that it cuts off as much of the concave part
as possible, resulting in an invalid construction with a better than possible score.
A simple fix is, instead of naively connecting the ğ‘ğ‘–by straight lines, to use the Lipschitz type bounds in 6.18.
That is, from every point ğ‘ğ‘–= (ğœŒğ‘–, ğ‘¡ğ‘–) given by AlphaEvolve, we extend a horizontal line to the left and a line
with slope 3 to the right. The set of points that lie under all of these lines contains all points below the curve
ğ¶6.46(ğœŒ). Hence, by setting the score of AlphaEvolveâ€™s construction to be the area of the points that lie under
all these piecewise linear functions, and asking it to minimize this area, we managed to converge to the correct
solution. Figure 25 shows how AlphaEvolveâ€™s constructions approximated the optimal curve over time.
28. Matrix multiplications and AM-GM inequalities. The classical arithmetic-geometric mean (AM-GM)
inequality for scalars states that for any sequence of ğ‘›non-negative real numbers ğ‘¥1, ğ‘¥2, â€¦ , ğ‘¥ğ‘›, we have:
ğ‘¥1 + ğ‘¥2 + â‹¯+ ğ‘¥ğ‘›
ğ‘›
â‰¥(ğ‘¥1ğ‘¥2 â‹¯ğ‘¥ğ‘›)1âˆ•ğ‘›
Extending this inequality to matrices presents significant challenges due to the non-commutative nature of matrix
multiplication, and even at the conjectural level the right conjecture is not obvious [29]. See also [30] and
references therein.
For example, the following conjecture was posed by Recht and RÃ¨ [239]:

Duchi [99] conjectured that ğ¶6.47(ğ‘›, ğ‘š, ğ‘‘) = 1 for all ğ‘›, ğ‘š, ğ‘‘. The cases ğ‘š= 1, 2 of this conjecture follow from
standard arguments, whereas the case ğ‘š= 3 was proved in [169]. The case ğ‘šâ‰¥4 is open.
By setting all the ğ´ğ‘–to be the identity, we clearly have ğ¶6.47(ğ‘›, ğ‘š, ğ‘‘) â‰¤1. We used AlphaEvolve to search for
better examples to refute Duchiâ€™s conjecture, focusing on the parameter choices
(ğ‘›, ğ‘š, ğ‘‘) âˆˆ{(4, 4, 3), (4, 4, 4), (4, 4, 5), (5, 4, 3), (5, 4, 4), (6, 4, 3), (6, 4, 4),
(5, 5, 3), (5, 5, 5), (6, 5, 3), (6, 5, 4), (6, 6, 3), (6, 6, 4), (7, 4, 3)}.
The norms that were chosen were the Schatten ğ‘˜-norms for ğ‘˜âˆˆ{1, 2, 3, âˆ} and the Ky Fan 2- and 3-norms.
AlphaEvolve was able to find further constructions attaining the upper bound ğ¶6.47(ğ‘›, ğ‘š, ğ‘‘) â‰¤1 but was not
able to find any constructions improving this bound (i.e., a counterexample to Duchiâ€™s conjecture).
29. Heilbronn problems.
Problem 6.48 (Heilbronn problem in a fixed bounding box). For any ğ‘›â‰¥3 and any convex body ğ¾in the
plane, let ğ¶6.48(ğ‘›, ğ¾) be the largest quantity such that in every configuration of ğ‘›points in ğ¾, there exists a triple
of points determining a triangle of area at most ğ¶6.48(ğ‘›, ğ¾) times the area of ğ¾. Establish upper and lower
bounds on ğ¶6.48(ğ‘›, ğ¾).
A popular choice for ğ¾is a unit square ğ‘†. One trivially has ğ¶6.48(3, ğ‘†) = ğ¶6.48(4, ğ‘†) =
1
2. It is known
that ğ¶6.48(5, ğ‘†) =
âˆš
3
9
and ğ¶6.48(6, ğ‘†) =
1

ğ¶6.48(7, ğ¾) â‰¤1

ğ‘›= 14, see [224]. See Figure 26 (middle and right panels) for a depiction of the new best bounds.
30. Max to min ratios. The following problem was posed in [132, 133].
Problem 6.50 (Max to min ratios). Let ğ‘›, ğ‘‘â‰¥2. Let ğ¶6.50(ğ‘‘, ğ‘›) denote the largest quantity such that, given
any ğ‘›distinct points ğ‘¥1, â€¦ , ğ‘¥ğ‘›in â„ğ‘‘, the maximum distance max1â‰¤ğ‘–<ğ‘—â‰¤ğ‘›â€–ğ‘¥ğ‘–âˆ’ğ‘¥ğ‘—â€– between the points is at least
ğ¶6.50(ğ‘‘, ğ‘›) times the minimum distance min1â‰¤ğ‘–<ğ‘—â‰¤ğ‘›â€–ğ‘¥ğ‘–âˆ’ğ‘¥ğ‘—â€–. Establish upper and lower bounds for ğ¶6.50(ğ‘‘, ğ‘›).
What are the configurations that attain the minimal ratio between the two distances?
We trivially have ğ¶6.50(2, ğ‘›) = 1 for ğ‘›= 2, 3. The values ğ¶6.50(2, 4) =
âˆš
2, ğ¶6.50(2, 5) = 1+
âˆš
5
2
, ğ¶6.50(2, 6) =
2 sin 72â—¦are easily established, the value ğ¶6.50(2, 7) = 2 was established by Batemanâ€“ErdÅ‘s [18], and the value
ğ¶6.50(2, 8) = (2 sin(ğœ‹âˆ•14))âˆ’1 was obtained by Bezdekâ€“Fodor [27]. Subsequent numerical candidates (and upper
bounds) for ğ¶6.50(2, ğ‘›) for 9 â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤30 were found by Cantrell, Rechenberg and Audetâ€“Fournierâ€“Hansenâ€“Messine
[55, 238, 8]. Cantrell [54] constructed numerical candidates for ğ¶6.50(3, ğ‘›) in the range 5 â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤21 (one clearly
has ğ¶6.50(3, ğ‘›) = 1 for ğ‘›= 2, 3, 4).
We applied AlphaEvolve to this problem in the most straightforward way: we used its search mode to minimize
the max/min distance ratio. We tried several (ğ‘‘, ğ‘›) pairs at once in one experiment, since we expected these prob-
lems to be highly correlated, in the sense that if a particular search heuristic works well for one particular (ğ‘‘, ğ‘›)
pair, we expect it to work for some other (ğ‘‘â€², ğ‘›â€²) pairs as well. By doing so we matched the best known results for
most parameters we tried, and improved on ğ¶6.50(2, 16) â‰ˆ
âˆš
12.889266112 and ğ¶6.50(3, 14) â‰ˆ
âˆš
4.165849767,
in a small experiment lasting only a few hours. The latter was later improved further in [25]. See Figure 27 for
details.

31. ErdÅ‘sâ€“GyÃ¡rfÃ¡s conjecture. The following problem was asked by ErdÅ‘s and GyÃ¡rfÃ¡s [118, Problem 64]:
Problem 6.51 (ErdÅ‘sâ€“GyÃ¡rfÃ¡s problem). Let ğºbe a finite graph with minimum degree at least 3. Must ğº
contain a cycle of length 2ğ‘˜for some ğ‘˜â‰¥2?
While the question remains open, it was shown [203] that the claim was true if the minimum degree of ğºwas suf-
ficiently large; in fact in that case there is some large integer ğ“such that for every even integer ğ‘šâˆˆ[(log ğ“)8, ğ“],
ğºcontains a cycle of length ğ‘š. We refer the reader to that paper for further related results and background for
this problem.
Unlike many of the other questions here, this problem is not obviously formulated as an optimization problem.
Nevertheless, we experimented with tasking AlphaEvolve to produce a counterexample to the conjecture by
optimizing a score function that was negative unless a counterexample to the conjecture was found. Given a
graph, the score computation was as follows. First, we gave a penalty if its minimum degree was less than 3.
Next, the score function greedily removed edges going between vertices of degree strictly more than 3. This
step was probably unnecessary, as AlphaEvolve also figured out that it should do this, and it even implemented
various heuristics on what order it should delete such edges, which worked much better than the simple greedy
removal process we wrote. Finally, the score was a negative weighted sum of the number of cycles whose length
was a power of 2, which we computed by depth first search. We experimented with graphs up to 40 vertices, but
ultimately did not find a counterexample.
32. ErdÅ‘s squarefree problem.
Problem 6.52 (ErdÅ‘s squarefree problem). For any natural number ğ‘, let ğ¶6.52(ğ‘) denote the largest car-
dinality of a subset ğ´of {1, â€¦ , ğ‘} with the property that ğ‘ğ‘+ 1 is not square-free for all ğ‘, ğ‘âˆˆğ´. Establish
upper and lower bounds for ğ¶6.52(ğ‘) that are as strong as possible.
It is known that
âŒˆ
ğ‘âˆ’7
25
âŒ‰
â‰¤ğ¶6.52(ğ‘) â‰¤(0.1052â‹¯+ ğ‘œ(1))ğ‘
as ğ‘â†’âˆ; see [118, Problem 848]. The lower bound comes from taking ğ´to be the intersection of {1, â€¦ , ğ‘}
with the residue class 7 mod 25, and it was conjectured in [105] that this was asymptotically the best construction.
We set up this problem for AlphaEvolve as follows. Given a modulus ğ‘and set of integers ğ´âŠ‚{1, â€¦ , ğ‘},
the score was given by |ğ´|âˆ•ğ‘minus the number of pairs ğ‘, ğ‘âˆˆğ´such that ğ‘ğ‘+ 1 is not square-free. This way


--- Page 59 ---
59
any positive score corresponded to a valid construction. AlphaEvolve found the above construction easily, but
we did not manage to find a better one. Shortly before this paper was finalized, it was demonstrated in [248] that
the lower bound is sharp for all sufficiently large ğ‘.
33. Equidistant points in convex polygons.
Problem 6.53 (ErdÅ‘s equidistant points in convex polygons problem). Is it true that every convex polygon
has a vertex with no other 4 vertices equidistant from it?
This is a classical problem of ErdÅ‘s [108, 109, 107, 110, 111] (cf. also [118, Problem 97]). The original problem
asked for no other 3 vertices equidistant, but Danzer (with different distances depending on the vertex) and
Fishburnâ€“Reeds [122] (with the same distance) found counterexamples.
We instructed AlphaEvolve to construct a counterexample. To avoid degenerate constructions, after normal-
izing the polygon to have diameter 1, the score of a vertex was given by its â€œequidistance errorâ€ divided by the
square of the minimum side length. Here the equidistance error was computed as follows. First, we sorted all dis-
tances of this vertex to all other vertices. Next, we picked the four consecutive distances which had the smallest
total gap between them. If these distances are denoted by ğ‘‘1, ğ‘‘2, ğ‘‘3, ğ‘‘4 and their mean is ğ‘‘, then the equidistance
error of this vertex was given by maxğ‘–{max{ğ‘‘âˆ•ğ‘‘ğ‘–, ğ‘‘ğ‘–âˆ•ğ‘‘}}. Finally, the score of a polygon was the minimum over
the score of its vertices. This prevented AlphaEvolve from naive attempts to cheat by moving some points to
be really close or really far apart. While it managed to produce graphs where every vertex has at least 3 other
vertices equidistant from it, it did not manage to find an example for 4.
34. Pairwise touching cylinders.
Problem 6.54 (Touching cylinders). Is it possible for seven infinite circular cylinders ğ¶1, â€¦ , ğ¶7 of unit radius
to touch all the others?
This problem was posed in [201, Problem 7]. Brassâ€“Moserâ€“Pach [44, page 98] constructed 6 mutually touching
infinite cylinders and Bozokiâ€“Leeâ€“Ronyai [43], in a tour de force of calculations proved that indeed there exist 7
infinite circular cylinders of unit radius which mutually touch each other. See [231, 230] for previous numerical
calculations. The question for 8 cylinders remains open [26] but it is likely that 7 is the optimum based on
numerical calculations and dimensional considerations. Specifically, a unit cylinder has 4 degrees of freedom (2
for the center, 2 for the angle). The configurations are invariant by a 6-dimensional group: we can fix the first
cylinder to be centered at the ğ‘§-axis. After this, we can rotate or translate the second cylinder around/along the
ğ‘§-axis, leaving only 2 degrees of freedom for the second cylinder. We will normalize it so that it passes through
the ğ‘¥-axis, and gives 4(ğ‘›âˆ’2) + 2 = 4ğ‘›âˆ’6 total degrees of freedom. Tangency gives ğ‘›(ğ‘›âˆ’1)
2
constraints, which
is less than 4ğ‘›âˆ’6 for 2 â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤7. In the case ğ‘›= 8, the system is overdetermined by 2 degrees of freedom.
Recently [96], it was shown that ğ‘›mutually touching cylinders was impossible for ğ‘›> 11.
One can phrase Problem 6.54 as an optimization problem by minimizing the loss âˆ‘
ğ‘–,ğ‘—(2 âˆ’dist(ğ‘£ğ‘–, ğ‘£ğ‘—))2, where
ğ‘£ğ‘–corresponds to the axis of the ğ‘–-th cylinder: the line passing through its center in the direction of the cylinder.
Two cylinders of unit radius touch each other if and only if the distance of their axes is 2, so a loss of zero is
attainable if and only if the problem has a positive solution. On the one hand, in the case ğ‘›= 7 AlphaEvolve
managed to find a construction (see Figure 28) with a loss of ğ‘‚(10âˆ’23), a stage at which one could apply similar
techniques as in [43, 222] to produce a rigorous proof. On the other hand, in the case ğ‘›= 8 AlphaEvolve could
not improve on a loss of 0.003, hinting that the ğ‘›= 7 should be optimal. In order to avoid exploiting numerical
inaccuracies by using near-parallel cylinders, all intersections were checked to happen in a [0, 100]3 cube.


--- Page 60 ---
60
FIGURE 28. Left: seven touching unit cylinders. Right: nine touching cylinders, with non-
equal radii.
It is worth mentioning that the computation time for the results in [43] was about 4 months of CPU for one
solution and about 1 month for another one. In contrast, AlphaEvolve got to a loss of ğ‘‚(10âˆ’23) in only two
hours.
In the case of cylinders with different radii, numerical results suggest that the optimal configuration is the one
of ğ‘›= 9 cylinders, which is again the largest ğ‘›for which there are more variables than equations. Again, in this
case AlphaEvolve was able to find the optimal configuration (with the loss function described above) in a few
hours. See Figure 28 for a depiction of the configuration.
35. ErdÅ‘s squares in a square problem.
Problem 6.55 (Squares in square). For any natural ğ‘›, let ğ¶6.55(ğ‘›) denote the maximum possible sum of side
lengths of ğ‘›squares with disjoint interiors contained inside a unit square. Obtain upper and lower bounds for
ğ¶6.55(ğ‘›) that are as strong as possible.
It is easy to see that ğ¶6.55(ğ‘˜2) = ğ‘˜for all natural numbers ğ‘˜, using the obvious decomposition of the unit square
into squares of sidelength 1âˆ•ğ‘˜. It is also clear that ğ¶6.55(ğ‘›) is non-decreasing in ğ‘›, in particular ğ¶6.55(ğ‘˜2 +1) â‰¥ğ‘˜.
It was asked by ErdÅ‘s [3] tracing to [116] whether equality held in this case; this was verified by ErdÅ‘s for ğ‘˜= 1
and by Newman for ğ‘˜= 2. HalÃ¡sz [160] came up with a construction that showed that ğ¶6.55(ğ‘˜2 + 2) â‰¥ğ‘˜+
1
ğ‘˜+1
and ğ¶6.55(ğ‘˜2+2ğ‘+1) â‰¥ğ‘˜+ ğ‘
ğ‘˜, for any ğ‘â‰¥1, which was later improved by ErdÅ‘sâ€“Soifer [117] and independently,
Campbellâ€“Staton [52] to ğ¶6.55(ğ‘˜2 + 2ğ‘+ 1) â‰¥ğ‘˜+ ğ‘
ğ‘˜, for any âˆ’ğ‘˜< ğ‘< ğ‘˜and conjectured to be an equality.
Praton [232] proved that this conjecture is equivalent to the statement ğ¶6.55(ğ‘˜2 + 1) = ğ‘˜. Baekâ€“Koizumiâ€“Ueoro
[11] proved that ğ¶6.55(ğ‘˜2 +1) = ğ‘˜in the case where there is the additional assumption that all squares have sides
parallel to the sides of the unit square.
We used the simplest possible score function for AlphaEvolve. The squares were defined by the coordinates
of their center, their angle, and their side length. If the configuration was invalid (the squares were not in
the unit square or they intersected), then the program received a score of minus infinity, and otherwise the
score was the sum of side lengths of the squares. AlphaEvolve matched the best known constructions for
ğ‘›âˆˆ{10, 12, 14, 17, 26, 37, 50} but did not find them for some larger values of ğ‘›. As we found it unlikely that a
better construction exists, we did not pursue this problem further.
36. Good asymptotic constructions of SzemerÃ©diâ€“Trotter. We started initial explorations (still in progress)
on the following well-known problem.


--- Page 61 ---
61
Problem 6.56 (SzemerÃ©diâ€“Trotter). If ğ‘›, ğ‘šare natural numbers, let ğ¶6.56(ğ‘›, ğ‘š) denote the maximum number
of incidences that are possible between ğ‘›points and ğ‘šlines in the plane. Establish upper and lower bounds on
ğ¶6.56(ğ‘›, ğ‘š) that are as strong as possible.
The celebrated SzemerÃ©diâ€“Trotter theorem [275] solves this problem up to constants:
ğ‘›2âˆ•3ğ‘š2âˆ•3 + ğ‘›+ ğ‘šâ‰²ğ¶6.56(ğ‘›, ğ‘š) â‰²ğ‘›2âˆ•3ğ‘š2âˆ•3 + ğ‘›+ ğ‘š.
The inverse SzemerÃ©diâ€“Trotter problem is a (somewhat informally posed) problem of describing the configura-
tions of points and lines in which the number of incidences is comparable to the bound of ğ‘›2âˆ•3ğ‘š2âˆ•3 + ğ‘›+ ğ‘š. All
known such constructions are based on grids in various number fields [13], [157], [85].
We began some initial experiments to direct AlphaEvolve to maximize the number of incidences for a fixed
choice of ğ‘›and ğ‘š. An initial obstacle is that determining whether an incidence between a point and line occurs
requires infinite precision arithmetic rather than floating point arithmetic. In our initial experiments, we restricted
the points to lie on the lattice â„¤2 and lines to have rational slope and intercept to avoid this problem. This
is not without loss of generality, as there exist point-line configurations that cannot be realized in the integer
lattice [269]. When doing so, with the generalizer mode, AlphaEvolve readily discovered one of the main
constructions of configurations with near-maximal incidences, namely grids of points {1, â€¦ , ğ‘}Ã—{1, â€¦ , ğ‘} with
the lines chosen greedily to be as â€œrichâ€ as possible (incident to as many points on the grid). We are continuing
to experiment with ways to encourage AlphaEvolve to locate further configurations.
37. Rudin problem for polynomials.
Problem 6.57 (Rudin problem). Let ğ‘‘â‰¥2 and ğ·â‰¥1. For ğ‘âˆˆ{4, âˆ}, let ğ¶ğ‘
6.57(ğ‘‘, ğ·) be the maximum of the
ratio
â€–ğ‘¢â€–ğ¿ğ‘(ğ•Šğ‘‘)
â€–ğ‘¢â€–ğ¿2(ğ•Šğ‘‘)
where ğ‘¢ranges over (real) spherical harmonics of degree ğ·on the ğ‘‘-dimensional sphere ğ•Šğ‘‘, which we normalize
to have unit measure. Establish upper and lower bounds on ğ¶ğ‘
6.57(ğ‘‘, ğ·) that are as strong as possible.12
By HÃ¶lderâ€™s inequality one has
1 â‰¤ğ¶4
6.57(ğ‘‘, ğ·) â‰¤ğ¶âˆ
6.57(ğ‘‘, ğ·).
It was asked by Rudin whether ğ¶âˆ
6.57(ğ‘‘, ğ·) could stay bounded as ğ·â†’âˆ. This was answered in the positive
for ğ‘‘= 3, 5 by Bourgain [40] (resp. [41]) using Rudin-Shapiro sequences [175, p. 33], and viewing the spheres
ğ•Š3, ğ•Š5 as the boundary of the unit ball in â„‚2, â„‚3 respectively, and generating spherical harmonics from complex
polynomials. The same question in higher dimensions remains open. Specifically, it is not known if there exist
uniformly bounded orthonormal bases for the spaces of holomorphic homogeneous polynomials in ğ”¹ğ‘š, the unit
ball in â„‚ğ‘š, for ğ‘šâ‰¥4.
As the supremum of a high dimensional spherical harmonic is somewhat expensive to compute computationally,
we worked initially with the quantity ğ¶4
6.57(ğ‘‘, ğ·), which is easy to compute from product formulae for harmonic
polynomials.
As a starting point we applied our search mode in the setting of ğ•Š2. One approach to represent real spherical
harmonics of degree ğ‘™on ğ•Š2 is by using the standard orthonormal basis of Laplace spherical harmonics ğ‘Œğ‘š
